statement: H. Degenerate Matrixtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputThedeterminantof a matrix2 × 2is defined as follows:A matrix is calleddegenerateif its determinant is equal to zero.Thenorm||A||of a matrixAis defined as a maximum of absolute values of its elements.You are given a matrix. Consider any degenerate matrixBsuch that norm||A-B||is minimum possible. Determine||A-B||.InputThe first line contains two integersaandb(|a|, |b| ≤ 109), the elements of the first row of matrixA.The second line contains two integerscandd(|c|, |d| ≤ 109) the elements of the second row of matrixA.OutputOutput a single real number, the minimum possible value of||A-B||. processed.result:
You are given a 2x2 matrix:

$$
A = \begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Find the smallest possible value of  ||A - B||, where B is another 2x2 matrix with a determinant of zero.  The norm ||A - B|| is the largest absolute value of the difference between corresponding elements of A and B. 

Output the smallest possible value of ||A - B||.

You are given a 2x2 matrix. Find the smallest possible difference between this matrix and another 2x2 matrix where the determinant of the second matrix is zero. The difference is measured by the largest absolute value of the difference between corresponding elements in the two matrices.
